title: Monday, 26th March, 2018

DM10:09am

Italian politics is never short of drama. It took only two days for the new Italian Parliament to elect the speakers of the two Houses (on Saturday), but the Centre-right came close to a break-up. Salvini and Di Maio, the leaders of the two winning political forces at the 4 March elections struck a deal on the two positions

DM10:09am

On the one hand, the 5SM rejected the candidacy of Paolo Romani, a prominent politician in Berlusconi’s Forza Italia, on the basis that he had some minor judicial issues in the past, and Berlusconi opposed the candidacy of Roberto Fico, a left-leaning leader of the 5SM. Di Maio even declined a meeting with Berlusconi.

11:09 am
DM10:09am

However, the drama came when Salvini sided with the 5SM and decided to support Anna Maria Bernini, a member of Forza Italia’s party but not the candidate designated by Berlusconi. Anna Maria Bernini said she was not available under a designation not coming from her party. In fact, the agreement with Di Maio was already in place, bypassing Berlusconi. Berlusconi was furious, and the Centre-right alliance was close to a nervous breakdown.

DM10:10am

The whole story is to be interpreted as a deliberate bombshell launched by Salvini to Berlusconi, who could only settle for a reduced-form compromise to save the alliance and pretend to count. It was also a way for Salvini to assert his leadership on the Centre-right.

DM10:10am

That's the Italian definition of "center-right" btw

11:10 am
DM10:10am

Moving towards a “nightmare scenario”? Does this whole story suggest that Italy is getting closer to a 5SM-League government? Probably Salvini, while re-asserting his leadership, has no firm intention to blow-up the alliance with Berlusconi. All the pieces of the Centre-right together can have the upper hand in a 5SM-Centre-right government, while running alone Salvini would be relegated to being a junior partner. However, should a broader alliance not work out, there would be a risk of an alliance between the League and 5SM to form a government with a limited mandate and with the objective of going to elections again in 6-12 months, after having changed the electoral law.

DM10:11am

What is going to be the next step? Official consultation by the President will only start on 3 April. In the meantime, the Centre-right will frantically try to poach MPs from other parties to form a government supported by an enlarged Centre-right coalition, following an exploratory mandate from the President. My guess is that this attempt will just fail.

DM10:11am

Then it would be the turn of Five Star

Mouselet Why is Italian politics quite this hatstand? You might say 'twenty years of zero growth', but at least the Japanese Berlusconis are less obvious
11:12 am
DM10:12am

Possible deal with PD, Center Right, but lets jump to market bit

Boycott What's Harrington saying on BBA?
DM10:13am

Financial markets should look at (1) any sign of a return to anti-euro rhetoric (including that for a parallel currency), (2) any sign of a departure from fiscal discipline, or (3) any significant unwinding of the labour market and pension reforms introduced in the past. If all three or just one happens, it would be a sufficient enough reason for financial markets to topple. It would be a significant and painful encounter for the new administration.

BE10:13am

(@Boycott: you understand what a paywall is and how it works, right?)

But they're selling some stock to Axel Springer! Mostly new stock.

11:15 am
BE10:15am

Purplebricks Group plc (AIM: PURP; "Purplebricks" or the "Company"), the hybrid estate agent, is pleased to announce that it has entered into an agreement with Axel Springer SE (through its subsidiary, Fünfundachtzigste "Media" Vermögensverwaltungsgesellschaft mbH) ("Axel Springer"), Europe's leading digital publisher, under which Axel Springer has agreed to make a £125 million strategic investment in Purplebricks by subscribing for new ordinary shares of £0.01 each ("Ordinary Shares") in the Company (the "Subscription") as well as acquiring existing Ordinary Shares from certain PDMRs of the Company (the "Share Purchase") at a price of 360p per Ordinary Share (together the "Strategic Investment"). Following the Strategic Investment, Axel Springer will own approximately 11.5 per cent. of Purplebricks' issued share capital, as enlarged by the Subscription, and Purplebricks will appoint Dr Andreas Wiele, an executive board member of Axel Springer and President Classifieds Media, as a non-executive director on Purplebricks' board of directors (the "Board").
The Board believes that this is a major strategic advance for the Company and that Axel Springer's expertise and funding should enable Purplebricks to achieve its strategic goals and global ambition more quickly and effectively.

BE10:16am

360p is a pretty generous premium against the live price, which is 289p.

BE10:16am

https://www.investeg...201803261043299121I/

In order to secure a shareholding in Purplebricks of sufficient size, Axel Springer has also agreed the purchase of an aggregate 6,944,444 Ordinary Shares (the "Sale Shares") at 360 pence per Sale Share, representing an aggregate value of approximately £25 million, from Michael Bruce (Group Chief Executive Officer), William Whitehorn (Non-executive Director) and Kenny Bruce (Global Sales Director). The Share Purchase is conditional on the Subscription becoming unconditional.
In connection with the Share Purchase, each of Michael Bruce and Kenny Bruce have agreed with Zeus Capital Limited, the Company's nominated adviser, that they will not dispose of Ordinary Shares held by them for a period of 12 months following completion of the Share Sale.

Fresnillo PLC (FRES:LSE): Last: 1,278, up 69.5 (+5.75%), High: 1,281, Low: 1,233, Volume: 560.68k
BE10:23am

Our commodities team is bullish on gold for the first time in more than five years based on higher inflation, rising EM wealth and concerns about an equity correction. While our economists are more bullish than Bloomberg consensus on expected 2018 Fed hikes (four vs. three) - we believe gold could actually outperform once the tightening cycle is complete.
Normally in a rising gold price environment we would recommend more leveraged names; however, with under-investment and the need to invest in replacement production, any excess cash flow is likely to go to higher capex. Because of this, we select stocks with a solid or growing production profile and low costs, where those with any excess free cash flow that can be returned to investors and grow dividends could be relative outperformers.

wayneJ PurpleBricks placings and sales are designed to ensure that the availability of shares at borrow desks is limited....
FitzLions @Pharma since a share can't be issued fully paid for less than its nominal value, there's a bit more flexibility if shares are issued at 1p compared to £1.

BE10:25am

[F]or the first 30-40 days of an equity sell-off, the average gold response has tended to be quite small. After this, we tend to see a stronger hedging response, and by the time the typical equity market hits its trough, gold is up over 7.5% on average. In summary, it can take time for gold to start to act like a hedge, but when it finally does, it has functioned well. In this context, our team is not particularly concerned about the recent lacklustre gold performance. Even if equity markets continue to weaken (and there are tentative signs that they might not), gold should eventually start to strengthen. One reason for this dynamic may be that gold is first and foremost a hedge against systematic risks. If a sell-off is brief, then it can be attributed to equity-market-specific factors such technical positioning, profit-taking or temporary liquidity issues. If the sell-off continues, then it is more likely to reflect (or contribute to) fundamental risks, such as the rising probability of a recession. In this case, demand for safe-haven assets tends to go up, boosting the price of gold.

Recent peer transaction multiples have averaged 9x EV/EBITDA, 15x EV/EBIT pre-synergies. Post synergies this falls to 7x and 10x respectively. Considering 2-6% of sales in synergies could suggest an M&A valuation of €34-51 per share. Our price target is set at €36 per share based on an EV/EBIT of 12x 2018E, in line with peers Mondi and DS Smith – the implied P/E is 15x vs Mondi and DS Smith both at 14x.

The market seems to expect peak earnings in 2018 for the containerboard sector (and limited share price upside), but we see a scenario where earnings shift up in 2018, stay high and rising further, with upside to share prices. We see secular positive demand from e-commerce adding 100-150bps to demand growth and, at least for now, a positive macro backdrop and limited new supply through 2019 (visibility is low for 2020) as primary drivers for our view.
■ M&A (downstream integration, consolidation) and organic capex opportunities (cost improvements, capacity expansion) add longevity to our constructive call on the group. For now, sharply lower OCC costs are a material tailwind that could add an element of positive earnings surprise in the March quarter and possibly beyond.
■ We maintain our positive view on the containerboard industry and reiterate our recently raised Outperform rating on Mondi and our longstanding Outperform rating on WRK. In conjunction with this report we raise our 2018, 2019 and 2020 WRK estimates by 2%, 22% and 28%, reflecting higher prices, lower corporate taxes and consolidation of the pending KapStone acquisition that WRK expects to close before year-end fiscal 2018. A higher share count and higher finance costs are partial offsets.

RBS has underperformed Barclays, Lloyds and the wider European market YTD. Part of this relates to a change in guidance at FY17 results: RBS no longer gives an explicit cost target for 2020 or a reduction target for 2018. But the underperformance doesn’t appear to reflect the change in UK rate expectations since the beginning of the year (implied policy curve has risen greater than 25bps for 1Y-3Y), and RBS’s interest rate sensitivity - on most recent disclosures, now amongst the most geared in Europe. With UK rates rising sooner than Europe, today’s share price and valuation (8.8x 2019E EPS, 12.1% 2020E RoTE) represents an attractive entry point, and we upgrade to Buy with a TP 305p.

BE11:02am

FINL is a very well regarded name in the space but, in common with a number of its peers, has found the last few years tough, as footfall to malls has reduced and innovation in footwear has waxed and waned. The stores are in good condition (80 refits in the last two years) but lack theatre and the range has lacked exclusives and the real cutting edge product, both of which are issues with which JD can help. The Finish Line fascia will remain to begin with but JD will trial some rebrands over time, using similar tactics to those seen in a number of European countries (and Australia). Finish Line management is being retained.

BE11:04am

A sensible deal at a sensible price: JD is purchasing Finish Line in cash, the deal leaving it with roughly £50m of net debt (FINL has $30m of cash). Using guidance and the Thomson consensus, JD is paying about 0.3x sales, or an EV/EBITDA multiple of about 6x: it’s only 4x peak EBITDA. Not every shareholder will be thrilled about the notion of taking on the US, but it is a key move in JD’s desire to be a global player, and on a decent multiple for such a large footprint, it strikes us as eminently sensible.
